ygData.subject: Re: GECCO 2008 Multiagent Paper Question
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Wesley, Sorry for the delay; I didn t have time to post while at GECCO last week. Data that doesn t fit into the overriding geometry is a challenge in

Hi Wesley,

Sorry for the delay; I didn't have time to post while at GECCO =
last week.

Data that doesn't fit into the overriding geometry is a challen=
ge in HyperNEAT.  Jeff Clune addresses it to some extent in his quadruped c=
ontrollers, which include a sine wave input that seemingly does not fit in =
with the other body-related geometric inputs:

https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/=
webfiles/publications/Clune-HyperNEATSensitivityToGeometry.pdf

Jeff essent=
ially just stuffs that input into an arbitrary location on the substrate.  =
It doesn't seem to stop it from learning, so that is indeed an option, alth=
ough it is inelegant.  

However, to me, it seems even more inelegant to so=
mehow try to kludge HyperNEAT into NEAT.  I'd rather stick with one or the =
other.  

I would suggest putting such information in a centered locations =
in their own layers, or in other dimensions (as you suggest), and sticking =
with HyperNEAT overall.  It may work well actually to make things like heal=
th and ammo actual geometric dimensions.  However, you could also let them =
be single nodes that are alone in their own layers, or in parts of the inpu=
t layer that are separated from the rest of it.  

Ultimately I think that =
it should be okay to provide that kind of information to the substrate beca=
use our brains certainly contain various types of unrelated information, su=
ch as the time of day and the angles of our knees.  These are in effect sep=
arated in space within the geometry of the brain, although they obviously e=
xist somewhere.

In any case, clearly what to do with this type of data is =
a tricky issue and others may have alternative suggestions and ideas.

ken
=


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, tansey@... wrote:
>
> Hi Ken,
> 
> Thanks fo=
r the clarification.
> 
> As a follow-up, do you have any suggestions on ho=
w to handle mixed geometric and
> non-geometric data?
> 
> For instance, if=
 you're evolving a bot for a FPS, you may have some geometric
> representat=
ion of the world. However, there may also be other relevant
> information l=
ike health or ammo. It seems like there are only three solutions
> right no=
w:
> 
> 1. Use regular NEAT and lose the regularity of the world.
> 2. Use =
HyperNEAT and force the health and ammo information to be represented as
> =
extra dimensions even though they can be handled by a single input node.
> =
3. Evolve a HyperNEAT agent separately then use its input(s) as secondary
>=
 input(s) to a regular NEAT controller.
> 
> Is there a fourth approach? Or=
 is there generally a preference for one of the
> above three approaches?
>=
 
> Wesley
> 
> Quoting Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>:
> 
> > Wesley, the =
main insight motivating r(x) is that it aligns the agent geometry
> > with =
the team geometry.  That is, the left side of the agent is on the same
> > =
side of the agent as the left side of the team, which is how it usually wou=
ld
> > be in the real world.  Nevertheless, you make a good point that the =
substrate
> > could be 3D as an alternative.  There is nothing wrong with d=
oing it that way
> > and it does have its own advantages.  In fact, we have=
 experimented with both
> > approaches to laying out agents for multiagent =
learning (although only r(x)
> > is in the GECCO paper), and both are valid=
.
> >
> > ken
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@> =
wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi everyone,
> > >
> > > I am working on a project that =
needs a substrate of more than 2
> > > dimensions. Looking at David and Ken=
's GECCO'08 paper, I would have
> > > expected a 3d substrate for the heter=
ogeneous agent experiment. Is there
> > > some insight I'm missing behind u=
sing the special r(x) function rather
> > > than making a 3rd dimension?
> =
> >
> > > Wesley
> > >
> >
> >
> >
>
